Introduction

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) and Angelman syndrome are distinct neurogenetic disorders that arise from abnormalities affecting the same chromosomal region:  15q11-q13.  These conditions are classic examples of genomic imprinting disorders, in which the phenotypic outcome depends on the parent of origin of the genetic material.  PWS results from the loss of function of paternally expressed genes in this region, whereas Angelman syndrome arises from the loss of function of maternally expressed genes.  Despite originating from the same genomic locus, the 2 disorders present with strikingly different clinical features and developmental trajectories.

Pathophysiology



Normally, imprinting is a physiologic phenomenon in which the expression of a small subset of an offspring's genes depends on the parent contributing the involved gene.  For instance, an allele inherited from the mother may be physiologically imprinted (silenced) by methylation so that only the allele from the father is expressed.  Disease occurs with absent expression of the normally active allele (ie, no functional gene product).



Two classic examples of imprinting disorders involving genes on chromosome 15q11-q13 are PWS and Angelman syndrome.  In this region, certain genes are expressed only from one parental allele, either maternal or paternal, whereas the other is silenced through imprinting; these syndromes occur when the active allele is absent or nonfunctional, and the silenced allele cannot compensate (

figure 1
):



  • Prader-Willi syndrome:  Loss of expression from the paternal allele leads to the absence of paternally expressed genes involved in hypothalamic development and neuroendocrine function (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Angelman syndrome:  Loss of expression from the maternal allele results in deficiency of several key maternally expressed genes, including UBE3A, an E3 ubiquitin ligase essential for synaptic development and plasticity.


Mechanisms causing either syndrome include:



  • Deletion of 15q11-q13 (~70% of cases):  Deletion of this chromosomal region on the paternal chromosome causes Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), whereas deletion on the maternal chromosome causes Angelman syndrome.
  • Uniparental disomy (UPD):  UPD results from a meiotic nondisjunction event that results in 3 homologous chromosomes in the zygote.  To restore chromosomal balance, 1 chromosome is lost during mitosis ("trisomy rescue"), and UPD occurs when the remaining 2 chromosomes are from the same parent.  If both retained copies are maternal (maternal UPD), PWS results (eg, no paternal genes can be expressed).  If both are paternal (paternal UPD), Angelman syndrome results (eg, no maternal genes can be expressed).
  • Imprinting errors:  These errors involve abnormal methylation or imprinting center defects that lead to inappropriate silencing of normally active genes.  For example, failure to activate paternal genes can cause PWS.
  • UBE3A mutations (specific to Angelman syndrome):  Mutations in the UBE3A gene disrupt its function even when imprinting is intact, leading to Angelman syndrome in the absence of a chromosomal deletion or UPD.

Risk factors



There are no modifiable risk factors for these disorders because they result from sporadic genetic and epigenetic events.  Factors that increase the risk of genetic events include:



  • Advanced maternal age.
  • Use of assisted reproductive technologies, potentially due to epigenetic instability during early embryo development.
  • Family history of imprinting disorders, which may suggest inherited imprinting center mutations or translocations.

Clinical presentation

Prader-Willi syndrome



In PWS, in addition to neurologic symptoms, hypothalamic dysfunction is prominent, contributing to endocrine abnormalities and hyperphagia (

).  Key clinical features include:



  • Hypotonia:  This can present with poor suck in infancy that can lead to poor feeding and a need for nutritional supplementation.  It can also lead to delayed onset of motor milestones (eg, sitting, walking).
  • Subsequent hyperphagia in early childhood, leading to obesity.
  • Mild to moderate intellectual disability.
  • Hypothalamic and pituitary dysfunction, resulting in short stature, cryptorchidism (failure of testicles to descend), and osteoporosis.


Other common features include skin-picking, behavioral difficulties (eg, irritability; tantrums, especially if food is restricted), sleep-disordered breathing (eg, obstructive sleep apnea and/or central apnea), and autistic features such as poor eye contact, speech deficits, and social deficits.

Angelman syndrome



In Angelman syndrome, the primary deficit is in neurologic function, with a characteristic phenotype that emerges in early childhood.  Key clinical features include:



  • Severe intellectual disability, with absent to minimal speech.
  • Ataxia and tremor.
  • Seizures, often starting at age <2.
  • Frequent smiling and laughter with a happy demeanor.
  • Microcephaly, often with postnatal onset.


Patients often have a fascination with water and other sensory-seeking behaviors.  Other findings may include sleep disturbances (eg, reduced need for sleep, difficulty staying asleep), gastrointestinal dysfunction (eg, reflux, cyclic vomiting), and self-injurious behavior.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of both conditions is suspected based on clinical features and confirmed by genetic testing:



  • DNA methylation analysis of 15q11-q13 is the first-line test for both conditions.  It detects approximately 99% of cases of PWS and approximately 80% of cases of Angelman syndrome.  If methylation is abnormal, fluorescence in situ hybridization or chromosomal microarray can identify specific deletions.
  • If no deletion is found, UPD testing or imprinting center analysis is performed.
  • For Angelman syndrome, if methylation is normal but features persist, UBE3A gene sequencing is pursued.


Patients with PWS often undergo further testing for endocrine dysfunction (eg, thyroid studies).  MRI of the brain in patients with PWS and Angelman syndrome is often normal but may show mild cortical or cerebellar atrophy.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for PWS and Angelman syndrome includes:



  • Down syndrome:  Caused by trisomy 21 and can present with developmental delay, short stature, and autistic features.  Characteristic dysmorphic features of Down syndrome include up-slanting palpebral fissures, epicanthic folds, and a flat nasal bridge.
  • Rett syndrome:  Caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene and mainly affects the female population.  Key features include loss of speech, stereotypical hand movements, and gait abnormalities after an initial period of normal development.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:  Can result in hypotonia and developmental delay but with extreme self-mutilation (eg, biting, banging self) and extrapyramidal symptoms (eg, dystonia, choreoathetosis).  It results from a deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase enzyme and can cause hyperuricemia.
  • Hypothyroidism:  Can present with short stature and cognitive deficits.  However, other symptoms, such as thyromegaly, lethargy, constipation, bradycardia, and delayed reflexes, are expected.
  • Phenylketonuria:  Can result in intellectual disability, seizures, and microcephaly.  Elevated phenylalanine levels are usually found due to a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase.

Management



Management of PWS and Angelman syndrome is multidisciplinary and symptom specific:



  • PWS often requires nutritional support in infancy, strict dietary control in childhood, behavioral interventions for hyperphagia and mood regulation, and endocrine management for growth, pubertal development, and bone health.
  • Angelman syndrome management focuses on seizure control, physical and speech therapy (including nonverbal communication strategies), and behavioral approaches to improve attention and sleep.


Genetic counseling is important in both syndromes to address the recurrence risk in families.

Prognosis



With appropriate supportive care, individuals with PWS and Angelman syndrome can have a near-normal life expectancy.  However, most require lifelong assistance due to persistent impairments such as hyperphagia and behavioral challenges in PWS and seizures, motor dysfunction, and minimal speech in Angelman syndrome.

Summary



Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes are imprinting disorders of chromosome 15q11-q13 with contrasting phenotypes due to the parental origin of the disrupted gene(s) (
